issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
I believe this to be a console problem and a regression. I know that the CLC returns more helpful info in many cases and it isn't being displayed.
Here's an example of what the proxy returns for a failed "RunInstances"
{"results": {"status": 406, "message": "Failed to verify references for request: RunInstancesType:594b4b6a-5d50-443d-bb25-3dfd7c1caea5:return=true:epoch=null:status=null because of: Unable to run instance emi-7AD23B4C in which the size 12884901888 bytes of the instance is greater than the vmType m1.small size 5 GB.", "summary": "Not Acceptable"}}

That'll be a little hard to parse into something... though I could look for "because of".. Should consult with CLC team on best way to extract info. The proxy currently truncates responses so we don't return huge stack traces.

Another error message example, with different format:
com.eucalyptus.ws.EucalyptusRemoteFault: Action:ProblemAction Code:CreateStorageVolumeType Id:RelatesTo Error: Total Volume Size Limit Exceeded volume: vol-2FB9411FTotal Volume Size Limit Exceeded volume: vol-2FB9411F
fields.summary: Console error messages lack helpful info from CLC

comments.body:
we really need to fix these eventually at the CLC. This may be something that could be fixed for 4.0 as an easy to fix high benefit thing if it's just changing the format of the error messages coming from the CLC to better indicate summary info that could then be used by any client tool to display something concise and user-friendly. 

The referenced message has lots of info and yet the summary says "not acceptable"... we really should have some kind of format for these messages that makes it easy to extract the why what where info in a reliable and concise way. 

This is definitely out of scope for 3.4.1. I would love to have a small team look at this effort soon if we could. This would improve our user experience significantly, and it can't be too difficult to do.

[~jloza], identified use cases can be resolve in a quicker fashion. General statements that CLC error messages and codes are not completely AWS compatible doesn't help the team to address issues in a timely manner.

[~kedwards] does every error message from the CLC have a "summary" field? If so, I would be happy to go through and note in individual bug tickets which ones have info in that field that is not helpful, and even suggest what text to replace it with. I will even fix the bugs myself if that is possible. Whatever it takes to get this working better.

The console could then use the contents of that field to provide helpful and concise error text to users, and hide the rest of the info until a user requests it.
[~jloza], sadly eucalyptus error codes/messages are not uniformed.  Thank you for creating tickets to address the needs of specific use cases.
[~dkavanagh]'s fix makes this a bit more clear, but still need to fix underlying issue.

When creating a new launch config while trying to generate an error from CLC, it failed to return a notification informing whether it passed or failed to create the new launch configuration. The javascript console on the Chrome browser displayed the error message below:

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot call method 'indexOf' of null support.js:383

if (msg.indexOf("because of:") > -1) {

For the testcase above, the selected image was from the snapshot-registered image and attempted to add ephemeral storage devices to the launch config using the advanced option,
Good catch. I'll have to run through a lot more scenarios, but I'm surprised by this one. I'll reproduce that first.

I tested this by creating a launch config with the name of an existing one and got a growler that said "Resource already exists" (same in Chrome and FF)

Could you let me know the exact steps to create this condition?

1. Register an image from snapshot.

2. Create a new launch config with the newly registered snapshot.

3. Choose the advance option and add storage devices options.

4. No notification returns and the javascript console reports an error.
